posts.name: Tharun
posts.cooked: Hey there I have a quick question about Bot Detection pipelines. For most of the games during the autonomous period most of the bots are typically leaving the starting point however in order to avoid colliding with each-other I would assume that you would have to create some sort of pipeline thats able to identify other bots. I threw this idea towards my programming team who said it was impossible and I was wondering if anyone has some insight on the matter.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: It’s not impossible , but that doesn’t mean it’s worth it. You would need a limelight with a coral for the pipeline and you could probably feed it into pathplanner’s A* subsystem. However, you would need thousands of pictures of bots to train the model on, and you’d probably need to get all of them yourself. This is all incredibly time-consuming, difficult and expensive. Bot detection is possible in theory, but in practice there are probably only a handful of teams that could do it, and even fewer that would benefit from it.
I agree that it’s not worth the time and effort. But if you wanted to, you could probably just detect bumpers.

posts.name: The Imagery Queen
posts.cooked:
Asher Olgeirson:

However, you would need thousands of pictures of bots to train the model on, and you’d probably need to get all of them yourself.

I will say that the blue alliance and various teams’ smugmugs would make this part a bit easier. However, it would still be time consuming to achieve robot detection.

posts.name: Asher Olgeirson
posts.cooked: It might, but you’d want most of your photos at the angle your camera would be mounted

posts.name: Jason Daming
posts.cooked:
You might even detect other bots as a note incorrectly but only red bots: IMG_4026 3024×4032 5.13 MB

IMG_4026 3024×4032 5.13 MB

IMG_4026 3024×4032 5.13 MB

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked: There are other options than vision.  A 360 lidar would certainly pick up other robots, and since you know where the stationary objects on the field were you could make a reasonably good guess if the other item is a robot or not.  Doing that fast enough to avoid collisions, however, would be the rub.  If we could send pose data between robots I’m sure some teams could manage it, but I think the payout would be pretty low.  Just plan on not running into other robots, and make your robot robust to disturbances.

posts.name: Caleb Marshall
posts.cooked:
Asher Olgeirson:

However, you would need thousands of pictures of bots to train the model on, and you’d probably need to get all of them yourself.

There’s a website called Dataset Colab that has pretrained models of notes and bots. I haven’t used it personally, so I’m not sure how good the models are.
